snippet: Fears that encrypted communication will prevent agencies from tracking terrorists are overstated, according to a study that included current and former intelligence officials.
abstract: Harvard study finds that alarm in intelligence community concerning encrypted communications is overblown, noting that governments have range of opportunity to conduct surveillance through network-connected appliances, toys and other devices; findings call into question demands from intelligence and security officials that companies like Apple give government 'back door' access to encrypted data; findings also raise privacy concerns about Internet-connected devices.
lead_paragraph: Fears that encrypted communication will prevent agencies from tracking terrorists are overstated, according to a study that included current and former intelligence officials.

headline.main: New Technologies Give Government Ample Means to Track Suspects, Study Finds
